utterances: Nice to have you with us here in Studio 3A today.
Thank you for having me.
And why are you so sure these are improbable results, impossible results?
Well, the results of the election just don't reflect anything that we know about Iran, both from the anecdotal evidence of the last minute surge for the reformist candidate.
Also, the history of voting patterns, what - how Ahmadinejad had done in previous elections, how previous second term presidents had done when they sought a second term.
There's really nothing in these numbers that stands up to much inspection.

They even went so far as to suggest that two of the reformist opponents to Ahmadinejad, lost the very provinces of which their ancestors come from, and they typically vote with some degree of ethnic solidarity in Iran.
So, I don't think anyone takes these numbers seriously.

Had they rigged the election with a little bit more subtlety, I think people would have been unhappy, there would have been a sense of frustration and disappointment, but there probably would have been less of a protest in the streets and you wouldn't have seen really the coalescence of a number of senior political figures including, of course, the primary reformist opponent in the elections, calling for public protest and for the elections to be wholly annulled.

There was an op-ed in this morning's Washington Post that cited an opinion poll conducted in Iran about three weeks before the election that showed people there prepared to vote for President Ahmadinejad about two to one, which is not inconsistent with what happened.
Well, and of course, the Post Web site has done its own analysis of that opinion poll and found it to be somewhat suspect.
It's very difficult to trust polling from Iran, particularly when it's done by groups that are based outside of the country.
But that's it.
I think we just don't know what the ultimate turnout was.
I am perfectly prepared to believe that President Ahmadinejad has a strong base of support both among the military but also among Iran's lower classes.
He's done a very good job of spreading money around the country and trying to build his own base.

And his nationalist message on the nuclear program, his constant accusations -and very specific during the campaign, accusations of corruption among the country's senior leaders - certainly do play to a wider array of Iranians than many of us would have liked to believe.
That was the surprise of the 2005 election when I think he did win at least the second round quite fair and square.
This time around, though, he had a number of disadvantages.
And it was - it simply is impossible that two-thirds of the Iranian electorate came out and said they want another four years of this man.
He has done such a disastrous job of managing the economy.
Iranians are dealing with double-digit inflation.
And that was really the primary issue in the campaign and the one which his opponents really hammered him on throughout.
We're talking with Suzanne Maloney of the - Senior Fellow at the Saban Center for Middle East Policy at the Brookings Institution on the Opinion Page this week.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
(LAUGHTER)
Let me ask you about the trip that you just made because there was some controversy over who paid for it.
And you've announced you're going to reimburse the group.
It was a Cleveland-based group, the Arab American Community Center for Economic and Social Services.
There were some reports that they had links to Bashar al-Assad.
They deny that.
Do they have links to President Assad?
Look, the facts are this.
This Arab-American nonprofit organization had sponsored my trip.
The trip was completely reviewed and approved by the House Ethics Committee.

Because people are trying to use this as a distraction away from the substance of the issue, which is ending the suffering of the Syrian people, I've decided to reimburse the organization for the trip.
Just to be clear, are you saying that this group does not have links to President Assad?
That's correct.
OK.
Congresswoman, thank you so much for your time.
We really appreciate it.
Thank you.
(SOUNDBITE OF THE CINEMATIC ORCHESTRA'S ""EVERYDAY"")
That is Congresswoman Tulsi Gabbard, a Democrat from the state of Hawaii.
This is WEEKEND EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Scott Simon.
We're delighted to broadcast our show this week from the studios of NPR West in Culver City, California.
Greater Los Angeles is a place of superlatives and stereotypes.
It's blessed with persistent sun, but gets struck by flashfloods, forest fires and earthquakes, and often gets swaddled in smog; that L.A.
term that's entered the language for what happens when fog mixes with car exhaust and factory smoke.
Millions of people come to visit Hollywood, Disneyland and Beverly Hills; millions from across the world begin new lives here in places like Pasadena, West Covina, East Los Angeles and Compton.
People like to mock L.A.
as being glitzy, flighty and goofy, but the people here get on the roads early to work hard - the highways strum with energy, collisions and ambitions.
Most people in L.A.
are not in the film business, but almost no one anywhere is immune to the dreams that are hatched here.
Now, we've shown some glimpses - large and small - of Los Angeles life through both hours of our program.
The American military death toll in Iraq has climbed past 2600.
Army specialist Thomas Barbeiri was in Iraq just four weeks before he was killed in combat.
His parents and three brothers say T.J., as he was known, was a history buff.
From member station WYPR, Mary Rose Madden has this profile.
In the D.C.
suburb of Gaithersburg, Maryland, Thomas Barberi's family gathers in their kitchen.
A friendly pack of dogs lays at their feet.
Bagels, coffee and photos of T.J.
in his military uniform are scattered on the table.
The family is trying to put together a eulogy.
Everyone seems to emphasize the thing that made T.J.
in his father words an acquired taste - his dry sarcastic wit.
And his mother, Carol Barberi, tells everyone about a letter T.J.
sent to a relative a few weeks ago describing what his life was like in Iraq.
It started out - she was reading it to the kids and she said, oh, he said this is - it's just like sleepaway camp.
We had bonfires we roast marshmallows and make Smores.
Unidentified Male #1: Yeah.
He was always talking like that - silly.
More recently she received a letter from her son that was bit more serious.
We got a letter from him yesterday.
He said I just talked to you a couple of hours ago, I couldn't tell you too much about, you know, the mission that I had, and he said, but it will be over before you get this letter.
I just want you to know not to worry, it's going to be easy.
And the very last thing he said, I can't wait to be home, and then he put three dots and he said, for good.
Everyone at the table talks about T.J's great intelligence.
He was reading encyclopedias in the fourth grade, and had an unusual knack for remembering military history.
But after high school graduation, T.J.
joined the volunteer fire department in Rockville, Maryland.
At the Third Engine Firehouse in Rockville, Robert James worked the Monday shift with T.J.
He describes his friend's favorite outfit.
The shift started at 5:00 o'clock, right?
T.J.
used to come in here at 5:00 o'clock with his army coat.
He had like one of them army fatigue coats that button down the side.
He actually wore the coat on calls.
You know, he wanted everybody to know he was an Army man.
That coat, along with his aviator sunglasses, was a typical uniform for T.J.
It was part of the reason no one was surprised when he announced he had joined the Army.
In fact, his interest in the military went back to his childhood.
He loved war films and there is even a photo of him dressed in camouflage for his seventh birthday.
Fellow firefighter Jimmie Ceevee(ph) says the fire department and the army have something in common.
The basis behind why a lot of people do it is the camaraderie.
We're all like a family here.
Ceevee was often T.J's partner, driving the ambulance on emergency calls.
He says T.J.
was there when you needed him.
He'd always find a way to calm all this stuff if there was a serious event.
He always made it a joke to make us feel better.
Now the Barbeiri family is retelling some of those jokes - as they remember T.J.
For NPR News, I'm Mary Rose Madden.
This is WEEKEND EDITION from NPR News.
Scott Simon is on jury duty.
I'm Linda Wertheimer.
Early this morning a 6.2 magnitude earthquake shook Yogyakarta, Indonesia.
More than 2,500 people are reported dead, thousands more are injured.
Howard Arfin is with the International Federation of the Red Cross and he joins us from Jakarta, Indonesia, about 250 miles east of Yogyakarta.
Mr.
Arfin, can you tell us what you've heard so far about the damage?
Hey, how're you doing?
That's never been a grammatical rule, either.
